Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Statistics] Reduce DB size by removing unused data - Platform dimension " (#3626) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This data is not used in any functionality today. We only track it because we have the data available at w3c-log parsing time. *It is questionable in terms of cost-effectiveness.*

We could still store it elsewhere (e.g. in Azure table storage). Or we could reconsider storing this data when revisiting the design of the NuGet statistics feature.

> **Note**
> 
> Even when we no longer import these datapoints into the stats database, we still have all the data in the w3c-logs we upload to blob storage.

### Impact on database

A database size reduction could be achieved totalling **5,172.03 MB** (or 5.05 GB)!

Removing these indices will also improve performance of insert/delete operations against the `[dbo].[Fact_Download]` and `[dbo].[Fact_Dist_Download]` tables.

In addition, we generate less churn on the data by avoiding clean-up operations.

The following database objects would become obsolete:

* Table `[dbo].[Dimension_Platform]` (size = 0.39 MB)
* Table column `[dbo].[Fact_Download].[Dimension_Platform_Id]` (size = 2,585.75 MB)
* Table column `[dbo].[Fact_Dist_Download].[Dimension_Platform_Id]` (size = 2,585.75 MB)
* Stored procedure `[dbo].[EnsurePlatformDimensionExists]`
* Stored procedure `[dbo].[CleanupPlatformDimension]`
* SQL Type `[dbo].[PlatformDimensionTableType]`
* Clustered index `[dbo].[Dimension_Platform].[PK_Dimension_Platform]` (size = 56 KB)
* Non-clustered index `[dbo].[Dimension_Platform].[IX_Dimension_Platform_UniqueIndex]` (size = 88 KB)

### Impact on jobs

The `Stats.ImportAzureCdnStatistics` job would no longer need to store the Platform dimension data, which would improve import speed, throughput, and overall performance of the job.

We could:

* avoid the need to check whether an Platform already exists, and if not, create it during import;
* avoid the need to retain already imported Platform dimensions into in-memory cache;
* reduce complexity of import by no more linking Platform dimension identifiers to the download facts.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Package Renames] Add new schema" (#7900) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Add the `PackageRenames` table to the database:

Column name | Type | Description
-- | -- | --
Key | Int | Primary key   (autogenerated by DB)
FromPackageRegistrationKey | int | The package that   was renamed. There is a unique constraint on the   "FromPackageRegistrationKey" and   "ToPackageRegistrationKey"Â    columns combined
ToPackageRegistrationKey | int | The replacement   package. here is a unique constraint on the   "FromPackageRegistrationKey" and   "ToPackageRegistrationKey"Â    columns combined
TransferPopularity | bool | True if the   "from" package's popularity should be transferred to the   replacement package.     This column is indexed.

We will also add the following column to `PackageRegistrations` table:

Column name | Type | Description
-- | -- | --
RenamedMessage | String,   nvarchar(max), nullable | The custom message   for renamed packages

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to check framework compatibility?" (#9604) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm using the `NuGet.Protocol` APIs to fetch metadata about packages. I wonder if there is a way to check whether a package, or more specifically, a framework is compatible with a specific target framework.

If my designated TFM is `netcoreapp3.1` and I compare it to `netstandard2.1`, I want this to return `true`.

I'm fiddling with the `NuGetFramework` type but it doesn't seem to have such a method.

```csharp
var isCompatible = NuGetFramework.Parse("netcoreapp3.1") == NuGetFramework.Parse("netstandard2.1");
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[CPVM-OnBoard] Spurious package downgrades for multiple p2p projects " (#9549) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

In the restore graph that has multiple project to project references a package that is direct reference can cause downgrade error. 

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
Download the attached project
Execute : 
cd DuplicateCPVMNodes\DuplicateCPVMNodes
msbuild /t:restore DuplicateCPVMNodes.csproj

### Sample Project

[DuplicateCPVMNodes.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4617588/DuplicateCPVMNodes.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "dotnet nuget push fails with -ss & -sk flags when using snupkg symbol format" (#9543) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: `dotnet.exe`
dotnet.exe --version: `3.1.201`
OS version: `Win10 v1909 (18363.815) / Linux Latest on GitHub actions`
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: `No`

1. Run `dotnet pack --include-symbols -p:SymbolPackageFormat=snupkg -c Release Core.csproj`
2. Generates `Core.1.0.0.nupkg` & `Core.1.0.0.snupkg`
3. Run `dotnet nuget push *.nupkg -s https://mynuget.org/v3/index.json -k xxxx -ss https://mynuget.org/v3/index.json -sk xxxx --skip-duplicate`
4. Throws an error `File does not exist (*.symbols.nupkg).`

FYR
https://github.com/AraHaan/GitInformation/runs/651127299#step:5:67

`dotnet nuget push` seems to look for `.snupkg` by default but when using `-ss` & `-sk` flags to specify a different source for symbols it looks for `symbols.nupkg` instead & causes the error

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet nuget push fails with -ss & -sk flags when using snupkg symbol format" (#9543) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: `dotnet.exe`
dotnet.exe --version: `3.1.201`
OS version: `Win10 v1909 (18363.815) / Linux Latest on GitHub actions`
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: `No`

1. Run `dotnet pack --include-symbols -p:SymbolPackageFormat=snupkg -c Release Core.csproj`
2. Generates `Core.1.0.0.nupkg` & `Core.1.0.0.snupkg`
3. Run `dotnet nuget push *.nupkg -s https://mynuget.org/v3/index.json -k xxxx -ss https://mynuget.org/v3/index.json -sk xxxx --skip-duplicate`
4. Throws an error `File does not exist (*.symbols.nupkg).`

FYR
https://github.com/AraHaan/GitInformation/runs/651127299#step:5:67

`dotnet nuget push` seems to look for `.snupkg` by default but when using `-ss` & `-sk` flags to specify a different source for symbols it looks for `symbols.nupkg` instead & causes the error

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "No verbosity switch on dotnet list packages so HTTP requests are invisible" (#9600) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe
dotnet.exe --version: 3.1.202
OS version: Windows 10, version 1909
Worked before? no

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new project, e.g. `dotnet new console`
1. Add a package, e.g. `dotnet add package NuGet.Packaging`
1. List deprecated packages, e.g. `dotnet list package --deprecated`

No HTTP `GET` and `OK` log lines are visible, unlike `dotnet restore --verbosity normal`, `dotnet nuget push`, and `dotnet nuget delete`. Especially when listing many packages or using `--include-transitive` it can lead to the command hanging for a long time without any visible output.

It would be helpful to have a verbosity switch like `dotnet restore` such as `--verbosity normal` to show the HTTP spew. This would allow understanding why the operation is slow and if one particular source is behaving badly.

You can do this investigation with restore via `dotnet restore --verbosity normal`.

I think it's right that the log lines are not shown by default (there are a lot sometimes) but there should be a way to see them without launching Fiddler or some other MITM proxy.

### Verbose Logs

> Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

Well, that's the problem... ðŸ˜‚

```
PS C:\Users\joelv\Desktop\testproj> dotnet list package --deprecated --verbosity diag
Unrecognized command or argument '--verbosity'
Unrecognized command or argument 'diag'
Usage: dotnet list <PROJECT | SOLUTION> package [options]

Arguments:
  <PROJECT | SOLUTION>   The project or solution file to operate on. If a file is not specified, the command will search the current directory for one.

Options:
  -h, --help                                Show command line help.
  --outdated                                Lists packages that have newer versions.
  --deprecated                              Lists packages that have been deprecated.
  --framework <FRAMEWORK | FRAMEWORK\RID>   Chooses a framework to show its packages. Use the option multiple times for multiple frameworks.
  --include-transitive                      Lists transitive and top-level packages.
  --include-prerelease                      Consider packages with prerelease versions when searching for newer packages. Requires the '--outdated' or '--deprecated' option.
  --highest-patch                           Consider only the packages with a matching major and minor version numbers when searching for newer packages. Requires the '--outdated' or '--deprecated' option.
  --highest-minor                           Consider only the packages with a matching major version number when searching for newer packages. Requires the '--outdated' or '--deprecated' option.
  --config <CONFIG_FILE>                    The path to the NuGet config file to use. Requires the '--outdated' or '--deprecated' option.
  --source <SOURCE>                         The NuGet sources to use when searching for newer packages. Requires the '--outdated' or '--deprecated' option.
  --interactive                             Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action (for example to complete authentication).
```

### Sample Project

[testproj.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4672506/testproj.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Controlling how a package's assets get consumed " (#9599) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version: 5.5.1.6542

dotnet.exe --version: 3.1.202

VS version: 16.5.5

OS version: win10 v1909

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

I'm trying to author a package to contains somethin in both tools and libs. According to this: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files
If I mark it as a developmentDependency, it prevents the package from being included as a dependency in other packages, which is what I want.
However, it also excludes compile-time assets from compilation, which I do not want.
Currently, when I consume the package I have to add compile; to the IncludeAssets of the PackageReference and then everything works, but this is cumbersome.
Is there a way to author the package so that I can control how the PackageReference gets created? E.g. so that it will add "compile" automatically.

To give a little more context, the tools are doing some code generation and for it to work the libs needs to be referenced. So I'm looking for something that's both a developmentDependency (Does not allow adding my package as a dependency), but still allows my package to have libs referenced.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Error NU3001 has 7 scenarios causing maintainability issues" (#9598) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
[NU3001](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu3001) error code has 7 scenarios where few of them are dependent upon [`Exception.HResult Property`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.exception.hresult) causing maintainability issues.

For e.g. https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/eb9ad919724e5ef435d6321b775868c9f2c0f9a2/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/SignCommand/CertificateProvider.cs#L59-L90

This logic broke tests in package signing logic when `dotnet` returns a different `HRResult` value. For e.g. NuGet/Home#9523

As per https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/36786#issuecomment-632193883, `dotnet doesnot guarantee the HResult values of most of our exceptions, depending on them is going to be fragile.`.

We need to re-evaluate all the 7 scenarios of NU3001 error code and implement code that doesn't reply on `Exception.HRResult` if possible.
